title: Glow in the Dark ID Tags

description.text:
Printed with Glow in the Dark ABS on a PRUSA.
Great for attaching to anything you need to find in the dark.
Several example .stl files below.

Print one of the .stl files if it matches the name you want.
or
Download and edit the Sketchup file to change to your own name.
All the examples are in it, as well as a blank.
Use the 3D Text tool.
Enter the desired name.
Select Terminator 2 font.
Set the extrusion to 0.
Set height to 30mm or so.
Place on the blank.
Scale as desired, do not push/pull yet.
Explode the text.
Push/Pull each letter to the bottom face of the blank.
select the entire ID tag and export to .stl.
Slice with favorite gcode generator.
Print.
Attach to anything you need to find in the dark.

author: alpe66

description.text:
**THIS IS A WORK IN PROGRESS**
Whens the last time you build a SSB rig? Well this was my first and not my last rig i will build. The bill of materials (BOM) is uploaded as a excel file. It contains all the parts i used, prices if i bought them. Along with the 3D printed parts file names. Included is some good photos of how it was put together, I don't feel like taking it apart. But some build tips i have is read the HfSigs wire up its how to wire it up. And keep the leads short.

Bitx 40 SSB Radio with Digital VFO (http://www.hfsigs.com/)

Case (http://www.ebay.com/itm/Plastic-Electronic-Enclosure-Project-PCB-Box-Case-Desk-Shell-Cover-200x175x70mm-/322017583916?hash=item4af9be632c:g:AGsAAOSwQYZWzXzJ)

VFO Knob: A 3d Printable knob see files, meant for a 1/8" set screw (see files) Updated 2/19/2017

Volume Knob: Really simple, use a 1/8" set screw to hold it on.

Screen Spacer: With a hole in the case the screen doesn't fit flat so i created a spacer, one thing wrong with it is that the small section i cut out to make fit correctly.

Mic and PTT: This is a two piece mic built with the parts included in the Bitx 40 kit. The only thing that is not included was an Old CB Mic Cable. The cable i have came off of an old raider 4020 CB. Did do a little work on the button on the mic, use a 1/8" pin 0.5" long and a cut down pin spring.

I will post more photos when i have time (3/5/2017)

title: Aukey USB-C to USB-A Adapter Lanyard Loop

description.text:
Lanyard loop for the Aukey USB-C to USB-A adapter that's cheap on teh Amazonz.

This is press-fit. There's no retention for the part, which I discovered when I dropped one into a hole in the bottom of my car that is inaccessible to any human. It works really well if the plastic film the adapter has on it from the factory is still present. That gives just enough tackiness to hold things secure.

My intent was for this to be clipped to my chandelier o' gear in my bag. If you use it on a keychain, it may not be secure enough. YMMV.

title: Laser Cut Settlers of Catan Board and Seafarers

description.text:
Summary

Custom Settlers of Catan Board to be Laser Cut!

Contains

  • Settlers 3-4
  • Settlers 5-6
  • Seafarers 3-4
  • Seafarers 5-6
  • Quick Test Etching/Cutting File

Overview

This is my custom laser cut Settlers of Catan Board. Most of the hexes are remixed from Settlers of Catan Board by shakalandro, Settlers of Catan 6 player interlocking - add your own graphics! by JeffGinger and Lasercut tiles for Settlers of Catan by jmne, however I created my own Ore, Gold, and Ocean Hexes as I was unhappy with the current options. All of my files have been cleaned up so that there are no overlapping lines that may cause issues in laser cutting. Additionally, I have my files in both inkscape SVG (where I created them) and CorelDraw X4 files which is the software I print from.

File Organization

For each variant of the game, I have both the hexes themselves as well as the borders that go around them. I was unable to fit the entire Seafarers print on my laser so I split it in half; I've included both the full and the split versions.

Suggested Settings

I use a laser cutter at Maker Works on an Epilog Helix 50W laser. I've loved my results from printing on 5mm Birch Plywood.
Most Recently I've gotten good results using these settings:

  • Rastering: 75/95
  • Vectoring: 12/100/2500

I'd suggest playing around with the settings until you're happy, by using the small test file I included (it takes about 1.5 minutes to print)

description.text: I found the files for the Butter Spreader Device by Alferez_Alberto to be a great design but a little incomplete. The Main Screw was hollow, and came apart like a slinky. The Extruder retaining ring broke off right away. The compactor seemed too weak at the joint where the cylinder and compactor head were joined. So I remixed them, making the screw solid and reinforcing all the joints. Now, this thing works great!! Try it yourself, you won't butter waffles, toast or anything else the old fashioned way, again!

description.text:
---CONTEST ANNOUNCEMENT!---

Netherforged Design Contest: I've been hard at work cranking out these Netherforged Dwarven Constructs lately, and frankly, I only have so many ideas. So, we've decided to hold a contest. Take a look through the existing designs in the collection and come up with your own dwarven automaton, siege weapon, or similar contraption, email your sketches/descriptions to us at [email protected] (Subject: Netherforged Design Contest) and, if we pick yours, I'll design it, print it, paint it, post it, and ship it to you. Deadline is February 25th, so get to your idea-anvil and start hammering!

This character was designed for our sci-fantasy tabletop RPG, Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder and for our modular wargaming system, Wayfarer Tactics (now in Second Edition!).

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

You can keep up to date on Netherforged pieces via this growing collection.

Enjoy!

title: Happy Happy Rainbow
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Having acquired enough filament colors to do a rainbow, I designed a two piece Happy Happy Rainbow. The rainbow itself was printed with 0.25mm level heights, with the g-code manually modified more or less per Modified_Gemini's instructions at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2044713. No supports were necessary.

The PLA in the rainbow is best removed promptly from the heated bed and then held in the arch position to cool- it actually holds its shape quite well by itself when cooled. I sanded the elephant-foot edges of the happy face to ease the fit. The base of the happy face could use some modification to make it more stable.

description.text: This is a quick and dirty eye lens for a Jawa costume. It's sized to fit a 5mm LED. There is a channel for routing the wire under the lens.

Printer:

Folgertech FT5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.12mm

Infill:

0%

Notes:

This is meant to be printed with 0% infill, minimal perimeters (I did 2; will be trying with 1 as well), in translucent yellow/clear filament.

Using 0% infill results in good reflection of light around the inside of the lens when the LED is inserted.

You'll need to drill out the end of the channel for the LED so that it can go all the way into the cavity of the lens. I had to do it this way so that the 0% infill thing would work as desired.

My RigExpert AA-54 was held in by velcro so I designed this bracket to hold it in place. I printed in PLA as that's all I've used at this point and everything seems to fit. Something a little less brittle may be better.

I am holding it in place inside the case with 3M VHB.

If you print it or have any suggestions on how to improve it I would be glad to hear them, I'm just learning all of this.

This is my first attempt at 3D design. I do not yet have a 3D printer, but have one on the way.

This is a cable management clip for organizing cables for under your desk, or elsewhere were cables need to be kept tidy.

Please provide feedback to let me know where improvements could be made, or if you make improvements.

I am hoping that there is enough space to slide/snap cables in and out, and that the plastic will flex a little to allow cables to snap into place, computer power cables may need to be fed through.

Currently set to 50 mm wide, with 2 mm diameter for screw hole.

This is my original design, and is subject to change, as it is still a work in progress.

Are all parts here?
What is the purpose of the slit that is next to the cutting blade hole?
What is the purpose of that channel to the back of the table? The one that runs the width of the table. Does something fit in that channel?
I believe that the MiniTableSaw_DremelMount should be extended to the height if the table so that it too rests on the (ground) and also provides additional support.

title: GT2 belt clip.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This belt clip is used to tidy up excess belt inside your printer or other devices that uses GT2 belt. The belt is folded over so the teeth mesh together and hold the belt tightly but not under strain. A cable tie guide notch is shaped into the open end if you want to use one, I don't as the part is shaped to hold the belt in place. This grip is better than the cable tie method shown in the user guide as it places less strain on the belt.

I use this as the tensioner on my belt on the X axis of my Anet A8. The belt turns around a pulley on the head assembly and folds back to this part where the grip is used to hold the belt under tension. Using this part the belt can be tightened in two-millimetre steps. This also allows the belt tension to be removed in under ten seconds should there be a need.

I printed with 100% infill as the part needs to be strong long term. I also tried with 0% and it seemed just the same on quick testing.

The yellow bearing part in this image is over here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2088370

title: GT2 belt turn bearing for Anet A8

description.text:
This is a very simple and small part. Rather than turning the belt around a screw on the X Axis of the A8 I made this little part to smooth out the turn a little. This also takes the belt away from the thread of the screw, protecting it a little.

On the A8 there isn't much space for this bush so the side is a little thin but that's OK as the screw still takes the pressure of the belt. The part is shaped to help keep the belt in place which must work as I've never had any problems with mine falling off. :-)

Printed in PLA at 100% infill to make it the strongest possible.

The yellow belt clip part is over here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2088345

A version with ventilation and recesses for M3 screws will be posted shortly, along with the SKP files once I clean up the sources a bit.

I've printed this with good results using PLA and no supports.

description.text: A 40mm x 40mm x 34mm Planetary gearbox designed to be mounted to a Nema 17 motor. It's gear ratio is 4.444:1 (40:9 for those who dislike decimals). Version 2 Now supports an M8 bolt for the output by default. Changing the output size no longer requires reprinting the entire assembly - just print the top half of the planet frame, and the cover. If you want the M6 version, print m6_output.stl as well. If you've already printed the M6 version, and want to convert it to M8, print m8_output.stl. Warning! This is difficult to print. Unlike Jag's design it doesn't have a lot of overhangs, but the gear teeth require a lot of precision.

Print it, assemble it, disassemble it, grind away at all of the strings and blobs that are making it jam, repeat until happy, then disassemble it one last time and grease it. One of the 608 bearings goes on the inside of the case. The other should be holding the end of the bolt in place, with a locknut, or a pair of nuts. I spent quite a lot of time just slicing it and looking at slic3r's output before committing it to plastic, and still printed it 4 times before I was happy with how it printed. Expect to have to print the gears slowly - I printed mine at 20mm/min, with a .35mm nozzle and .25mm layer height. The .scad is fairly parametric, so you can adjust the number of annulus and planet teeth to produce different (and probably unprintable) gear ratios. This is marked as a work in progress, because I intend to use it to drive an extruder, and still need to design the extruder body. Vitamins:
Â Â 3 M3x12 Socket Head Cap Screw
Â Â 4 M3 Nut
Â Â 1 M3x6 Set Screw
Â Â 4 M3x35 Socket Head Cap Screw
Â Â 1 M8 Hex Head Cap Screw or 1 M6 Hex Head Cap Screw
Â Â 2 608ZZ (8x22x7) or 126ZZ (6x12x4) Ball bearing.
Â Â 1 M8 or M6 Nylok Nut

comments.text: The formula for computing the gear ratio of this sort of planetary gearbox is (R+S)/S, where R is the number of teeth in the ring gear, and S is the number of teeth in the sun (drive) gear, so (9+31) to 9, or 40 to 9, or 4.444 to 1.

comments.text:
I printed a set with a 0.5mm nozzle and ABS, using Cura slicer. It gives very good precision on small stuff.
I used 0.28mm layers. Next time I will select 0.24mm layers. Slic3r doesn't seem to handle small accurate detail as well as Cura.
You need the settings so that it has at least 3mm walls so that all the gears teeth are fully formed.
I am using Repetier for the printing. Never tried anything else.
I intend to make a sun gear in nylon, or even a full set of parts. Pretty weed eater cord.
With ABS make sure you lubricate the spigots on the planet carrier else they can seize.

description.text:
Three different mounting options to mount the mini differential IR height sensor by dc42 on an AnyCubic Kossel printer. May fit other effectors as well and the one that clips on the heaterblock should fit any V5 heaterblock.

  • A mount for the sensor on the 40mm hotend fan, as in the photo. Add washers to the M3 bolts that bolt the mount to the fan to ensure the sensor is not tilted.
  • The second one clips on the effector, between two diagonal rods.
  • Lastly, a mount that clips the sensor to the V5 heaterblock that ships with the AnyCubic printers. This needs to be removed before printing but having it that close to the nozzle allows for a larger probe area diameter and (possibly) more accurate calibration.

Thanks to dc42 for designing this really nice sensor.

Printer:

AnyCubic Linear

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 or 0.2

Infill:

solid

comments.text: How is the sensor ? Its anygood ? Can you tell us the steps you made to calirbate the firmware?
comments.author: Silenium

comments.text: The sensor itself works well enough. However, whether or not you get good results really depend on the surface you're using it on. When using PEI for example you have to paint the underside of the PEI matt black before sticking it to the glass (if that's what you're doing). Painting the glass doesn't work I found because of the adhesive layer (3M 468 adhesive in my case) between that throws off the sensor. So for PEI you have to use sheets that don't come with a pre-applied adhesive layer. Even when you've set it up properly, even minor wear of the PEI sheet will likewise throw off the sensor and give inconsistent results. With Delta printers there's the added issue of effector tilt (depending on your build) which can also affect probing to a degree where the results are not usable. This can be mitigated by a good build and having the probe as close to the nozzle as possible (or ideally, temporarily replacing the nozzle or mounting the probe exactly on the nozzle position) but for a permanently mounted probe on an imperfect Delta build it can be a big issue.
comments.author: Silenium

title: Extendable Modular Tube Container
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A truly modular storage solution in a tube. You can custom configure it's length and the amount of storage per cavity inside. You can create one long tube of have it divided up into small segments to securely store small things separately from other items in different compartments.... but all within the same tube.

There are seven components that let you make a storage tube as long as you want by combining the parts to suit. The parts are as follows:

Male Cap: The male end cap. This is very shallow so treat it as a cap to your tube.

Female Cap: Two versions are provided. The standard cap has an internal height / space of approx. 25mm. The Tall version has an internal height / space of 40mm.

Centre Sections Hollow: This part acts as a spacer / tube extension approx. 35mm and 50mm in length (2 files).

Centre Section Dividers: This part has a base that acts as a divider. The internal storage height / space is approx. 33mm and 48mm (2 files called 35/50 as per the hollow equivalents but with a 2mm base).

By combining the above components you can create a tubular storage solution to suit your needs... make it long and hollow or just a simple short container... and add divisions that keeps small items separate and can be accessed individually. Practical and versatile storage for small things...

Print parts to suit your needs and use different colours to identify sections / contents within your Extendable Tube Container. Colour coding makes it easy to find and access the items / section required while all other sections remain closed / sealed.

Please refer to the print settings and images for additional information. And, post images of your Extendable Tube Containers for other members to see.

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator+

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard / 0.20mm

Infill:

PLA / 2 Shells / 20% or greater

Notes:

Easy prints... use higher than standard infill to ensure the prints are strong and durable.

Nothing to do... just print then screw together and your tubular storage solution is ready to use.

Refer to the images and use a quick spray of silicone to make the threads turn really smoothly... dry PLA tends not to bind so surfaces do not run smoothly passed each other.

title: Makergear M2 Rev E bed swivel clip

description.text: This is a single Makergear M2 (Rev E) bed swivel clip, created on Autodesk Fusion 360. It is for use on a Rev E model printer to hold down the factory glass bed.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

MakerGear M2

No

Infill:

100%

Notes:

This part may be a fraction of a mm out from the original but will work well once screwed into place. I printed it at 100% infill for maximum strength. As it's a small part ensure your bed is level before starting.

Description

Due to wear and tear (and early bed-levelling errors which saw me raising the bed height with the swivel clips still in place) my bed clips started bending then a couple of them snapped. I couldn't find this part anywhere on the Makergear website nor anywhere else on the web so made my own. You'll notice that it may feel a bit loose when slotted into the circular recess on the bed corner, however once you screw it into place it will clamp down nicely on the bed & hold it firmly in place. I printed it in PLA with 100% infill and they seem to be holding up well. With a material cost of a few cents, if these break, just print more!

author: Reeydz

description.text:
Looking through the lampshades on here, there were no uplighters; I made one :-)

This is modular, 17 structural pieces and 17 panels all printable on a 200x200x200 bed.

For printing:
Rotate large frame sections by 45 degrees if needed to fit more centrally on build plate, it is also possible to print all frame sections standing upright; this gives pretty good results but can push your Z limit, check before you print, also, doesn't require support, but would recommend a brim to make sure they don't fall over.
let the thin panels cool before pulling off build plate otherwise they will be bent (my impatience taught me this).

I used PLA, clear for the frame pieces, middle octagon and, anchor piece.
Then candy red,green,blue and orange for the panels.
Included are a couple of patterned panels i threw together as a demo, I will probably add more at some point as i want to experiment with bas-relief stuff.

Also, using glow in the dark filament will be quite cool.

If you make this, please leave a comment or a 'make', I would love to see what people do with this :-)

openSCAD file included for people to tinker; the size is adjustable but the assembly view doesn't position properly; the bits should all fit though.

remove support material if needed

file holes/prongs to make a good fit

when happy with fit, glue frame sections together (i used epoxy resin)

if upper surface of panels is rough, this can actually help with a friction fit in the frame sections.

no glue should be needed on the panels (unless you want to of course), this allows for swapping out for new panels when you fancy.

Use thin string to attach 4 bits of the frame to the anchor, drill out holes if needed, I used fishing line as its strong and unobtrusive.

title: Weinsberg CaraOne (not only) 390QD air suply deflector

description.text:
Last winter I didn't empty all the conduits in my Weinsberg Caravan as I came home from vacation. It was very freezing outside so I decided to empty all the conduits to prevent damages. As I did this, I noticed that the conduits in the back, under the seats, were still frozen after about an hour of heating. This was due to the air suply that is needed for ventilation. It is built in the bottom of the caravan, directly beneath the conducts and the pipes for the heating. So all the cold air from outside directly hits these pipes.
I decided to measure the suply and build a deflector, that guides the air from the outside past the pipes.

Maybe the same suply is used in different Weinsberg and/or Knaus Caravans.

German:
Letzten Winter habe ich nach einem Urlaub nicht alle Wasserleitungen komplett entleert. Als es dann draußen sehr kalt wurde wollte ich alle Leitungen leeren. Also Caravan (Weinsberg CaraOne 390QD) 1 Stunde durchgeheizt und alle Abläufe geöffnet. Ich habe dann bemerkt, dass hinten, unter der Sitzbank, das Wasser gefroren blieb. Verursacht wurde dies durch die Zwangsbelüftung im Boden des Caravans, welche sich direkt unter den Wasserleitungen und unter dem Heizungsrohr befindet. Durch die große Temperaturdifferenz kam sehr viel kalte Luft durch die Lüftung und kühlte die Leitungen stark ab.
Ich habe dann die Zwangsbelüftung ausgemessen und einen Abweiser erstellt, der die Luft an den Leitungen vorbei leitet.

Wahrscheinlich wird diesselbe Belüftung auch in anderen Weinsberg und/oder Knaus Wohnwagen oder Wohnmobilen verwendet.

description.text:
This is a remix of AlexCphoto's great "Needle File Handle w/ Thumb Set Screw" (Thing 216145).

AlexCphoto's version seems to be a convertible approach where he uses one handle with a big thumb screw that allows quickly changing the file.

I wanted a separate handle for each file so I made some minor changes to accommodate a M3x5 socket head cap screw with hex drive and an according M3 nut. This way, the screw protrudes only slightly from the handle.

Check these Magnetic Needle File Holders Mark I or the revisited version Mark II if you need an easy-to-use wall mounted file holder with magnets.

description.text:
A nightstand organizer that accommodates your phone, keys, wallet watch and possible other stuff that you can cram in there.

Requires 1/2" material and LaserWeb4 to open the file.

Gcode generated in LaserWeb4 and sent to machine via LaserWeb3. To know more about those visit:
https://github.com/LaserWeb/LaserWeb3

When Amazon change their devices, like everyone else, they render their old cases and accessories obsolete for the sake of a few millimetres.

So I decided to use my brand new Kindle Paperwhite in my old Kindle Touch 3G case. Because it's big and sturdy and looks awesome. And it cost a few quid, too, back in the day.

Note: Scale to suit!

This tends to work well and would probably be fine in all scenarios but you'll need to print a few and scale the Y and Z axis appropriately. To secure my Paperwhite 3G into my Touch 3G case I had to scale the Y axis by 1.5 and the Z axis by 1.2, but you can adapt these variables to suit your tolerances required!

This is a tool tidy i designed to hold all the tools and bits I usually have strewn across my desk. It is designed to hold:

  • 24x screwdriver bits
  • 5x pairs of tweezers
  • 5x Soldering Iron ends
  • 2x Electrical tape rolls
  • 1x Swiss army knife
  • 1x Leatherman Fuse
  • 1x Turnigy Hex screwdriver
  • 1x screwdriver handle
  • 1x screwdriver extender
  • 1x calipers

I never originally uploaded this as I thought it would be too specific a range of items to be useful to anyone else but I've had a few requests to upload so here we are.

Now the model isn't perfect, it fits everything, but at the moment, the design uses pillars to slot the soldering iron ends onto. This works but they come out rather weak so can break fairly easily. The screwdriver ends all fit fine but it is a little tight so getting each out the first few times can be a bit stiff but that does improve over time.

The soldering iron tips, electrical tape reels, tweezers, calipers and screwdriver tips are all standard sizes, but here's the dimensions of the rest of my tools:

  • Swiss Army Knife: 19.5 x 21 mm
  • Leatherman (Fuse): 30.5 x 17.5 mm
  • Turnigy hex driver: 14.65 mm
  • Screwdriver extension: 4.75 mm
  • Screwdriver: 17.3 mm

I hope you enjoy printing and using my design. To help me keep designing and uploading more things, as well as continue to run my YouTube channel (www.youtube.com/c/3drevolution), please consider making a small donation to me via PayPal: www.paypal.me/JoshForwood
Thank you!

description.text:
This is currently a work in progress and the X axis rail mount is a mash-up of 2 mounts to create this 1 that will convert the X axis on an Anet A8 to a more solid 2020 extruded beam.

Please note my converted part is labelled anet_a8_2020_x_axis_conversion.stl all the other parts are created by the original maker. You will also need both of the converted mounts as 1 is mirrored for the opposite side

I combined the z mount from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1718315 and the z mount from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1285301 along with a bit of tidying up to create the converted mount

Update: Initial/prototype converted mount printed and picture uploaded. Z axis holes are in the correct position for the Anet A8 (late 2016/beginning 2017 version) and the height is equivalent to 2 LM8UU bearings so should work nicely with 2 Igus Drylin equivalents.

Update 7th Feb,
I have created a smaller x axis mount that only requires 1 LM8UU linear bearing and also made 1 wall slightly thinner to allow the mount to sit the 2020 extrusion behind the Z axis rods and not interfere with the printer frame and look a lot tidier. In the next day or 2 I will be getting my 500mm 2020 beam to test all the printed parts onto.

Mostly for my own record I have added an E3D v6 mini gantry mount with 12mm and 18mm sensor mounts from 2 other 'thingies'

Update 8th Feb,
Beam testing today and everything is looking good. On initial tests it looks like the build height could be increased from 240mm to 270mm and as the 2020 beam sits behind the Z axis rods there isn't any immediate impact on the Y axis. Also uploaded a video to youtube showing the smooth movement and due to the way the belt will be tightened there will be zero impact on the Z axis which should help reduce noise and vibration https://youtu.be/8akLz3m-cEQ

Added a 3D printable version of the mini gantry plate from DarkAlchemist http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:471978 along with a comparison of my current x carriage and the new one

Update 11th Feb,
Project now complete and is working great on initial test https://youtu.be/ECcMDMCDuK0

Update 12th Feb,
Uploaded a different part cooler as I felt the one I was using wasn't close enough to the hotend and was causing cooling issues on prints

13th Feb, Added an UNTESTED mount for the Geeetch i3X 27mm spacing, -see comments

Update 15th Feb,
After I did my conversion I had found that a hidden issue had arisen with my Z axis which turned out to be faulty couplers which were off-centred. Today I got my replacements through and not only is the initial print much better but I have found especially with this conversion that the printer has become quiet https://youtu.be/ODVt6cMiV10

Update as requested in the comments,
The way I found that I had an issue with my Z axis was by elimination. On a test print I printed 1 of the floating boats to compare with a previous one (silver) and found the new one was all over the place (it is also the best example of the bad prints). I then looked at my belts whether they were too tight or too loose and they were actually fine and then I noticed what was a bad 'wobble' on the lead screw so I tried to adjust them and whilst a test print did improve slightly there was still a 'wobble' in the Z axis. So I then checked the straightness of the lead screws and they were straight and then I tested the motor shafts for straightness by removing the couplers and they were fine. I then noticed the couplers wouldn't seat straight no matter how hard I tried I got it close but it still 'wobbled'. As it turns out the couplers were off-centred on the 5mm hole side as tested with a 5mm drill bit held in place with the grub screws. I then received my new couplers today (15th Feb) and tested them out and found they worked as they should as shown in the picture of 2 tubes 1 being the original with original couplers and the other with the new couplers and both were printed at 200c/60c and both at 280mm high and a 0.2mm layer height. So from this elimination I feel some of the common Z axis wobble is actually down to faulty couplers.
Original couplers: https://youtu.be/8lr8jr46DQM
Replacement couplers: https://youtu.be/lBMSM4ktCM4

I had a few questions on Facebook about the purchased parts and thought I had put a list here but hadn't so here it is

Purchased parts were
1x 20x20x500mm Black extrusion beam
1x Openbuilds V-Slot Mini Gantry
1x Openbuilds idler wheel
5x 10mm M5 low profile bolts
1x 2m GT2 belt (got enough left to change my Y axis belt )
2x Igus Drylin RJ4JP-01-08 (actually came as free samples from Igus)

I got all my parts from www.ooznest.co.uk

comments.text:
Autro,
I modded Gavin's design for a 20x40 rail (that's what I had on hand) and the stock extruder assembly. The only issue is the heat distribution of the stock assembly - you can't mount the stock extruder on plastic. I used a metal bracket (2in x 2in steel angle) and cut down an Openbuilds 80x20 gantry plate for it.
I also built it on a printed gantry plate with this bracket:
http://www.banggood.com/42MM-NEMA17-Stepper-Motor-Alloy-Steel-Mounting-Bracket-With-Screws-5x5x5cm-For-3D-Printer-p-1013106.html
Both assemblies work much better than the stock 8mm round rails, even with the stock head.

That's great, in a lot of ways my design evolved around the E3D which is a great hotend but not many people want to change over to the E3D.
It is also great to hear that I am not the only one finding this setup is much better the parallel rods and thanks to my experience I am costing up the option to swap the frame to the Hypercube frame which should allow for even better printing quality.

comments.author: gavincol78

comments.text: I am using a top quality clone that is 1:1 clone with a full metal throat. I have not had a genuine E3D v6 but from various youtube videos if you get the right clone then the performance is on par with a genuine. As for a comparison between the stock setup and the E3D (I have mine in a bowden setup rather then direct drive which makes a difference) there is no comparison especially in a bowden setup (flexi filament could still be used using a few tutorials on YT). With the stock setup there is a lot of weight across the X axis which can lead towards ghosting and ripples however in a bowden setup there is almost no weight which not only reduces the kinetic forces but also minimises vibrations.

title: Prusa Steel Lead-screw x-axis
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
X-axis lead-screw system for prusa i3 steel or any other prusa styled printer with 17 mm between linear bearing and z axis screw

X-motor: has an integrated mount for a mechanical endstop
X-idler: has built in belt tension system, where the force is applied through the x-axis instead of onto the z-axis.

The tension system use M6 nuts and bolts, and i recommend redrilling all holes after printing and seating all nuts using a soldering iron.

Part of the design was inspired by the designes made by toolson, and it is compatibel with his z-endstop mount.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Steel

Rafts:

No

description.text:
I had many pairs of sunglasses throughout my house and car so I made this to keep them all together and stop them from getting damaged.
Hang your glasses on the wall near the door so you can grab a pair on your way out.

You'll need a 12mm square dowel, mine was laying around from an old project. Drill a hole at the top to fit over an existing picture hook.

The printed rest acts like a peg on the dowel, there is a hole in the front to screw through if you wish to secure it, I didn't need it.

It works best on glasses frames that have thin arms, these sit flat. Thicker arms make the glasses look downward. Also frames that are deeper than 50mm will not fit on the rest.

author: buffcleb

description.text:
This is a simple laser-cut Minecraft chessboard, great for use with 3D-printed chess pieces. The design includes a sword covering the board and characters around the perimeter. Some post-cut work is required.

  1. Setup files for your laser cutter. The SVG file includes red cut lines and greyscale raster images designed for a single job. The lines and images may need to be separated, and the line color/thickness may need to be adjusted for your cutter.

  2. After cutting, number each square as you remove it from the cutter.

  3. Lay everything into position on a table. There will be a gap between the perimeter pieces and the squares due to material loss during cutting. Sand the inside corners of the perimeter pieces to ensure a tight fit.

  4. Stain the perimeter pieces and alternate squares. The lower-left square (1A) should be dark.

  5. Glue everything to a flat base layer such as MDF, taking extra care to spread glue all the way to the edges and corners. A wet brush helps to spread the glue evenly. Clamp until dry.

  6. Apply gloss or top coat as desired.

author: cyberman

description.text:
Fair warning, this project is fairly complex and involved. Total disclosure, this is not a perfect design, however it seems to have worked well so far. If anyone would like to contribute suggestions, I am more than happy to incorporate them into the CAD. End disclosure.

This is a comprehensive enclosure designed for a Arduino Mega 2560 / RAMPS 1.4 / 12864 LCD combination. Enclosure includes 30mm case fan for board cooling, 6x 8P DIN connector ports for wiring (designed with a DeltaBot in mind, one port each for X/Y/Z, extruder motor, end effector, and heated bed), slotted vents for air flow, and cutouts for USB to the Arduino and power to the RAMPS. The RAMPS enclosure is magnetically joined to a similar enclosure for a 12864 LCD controller. The LCD enclosure has all appropriate cutouts for the trimmer pot adjustment, reset button, rotary encoder, and SD card slot (also has slotted face over buzzer).

Spare parts required:
-3x M3 threaded heat set inserts
-6x 8P DIN connectors (female)
-6x 8P DIN connectors (male)
-1x 30mm case fan (12V)
-8x 6mm diameter, 3mm thick neodymium magnets

I will leave the materials and requirements for wiring the DIN connectors up to you. Please know that this is fairly involved.

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

The assembly of the enclosure is fairly self-explanatory. Take care to install the magnets in the correct orientation in both sides of the enclosure, so that they attract when putting the enclosure halves together.

Again, I will leave the wiring up to you, as you may pin it out any way you would like. I grouped the endstops and stepper motors for each axis together (1 harness each for X, Y and Z). I ran one harness for the extruder motor (E), 1 harness for the bed heater and thermistor (B), and 1 harness for the hot end and thermistor (F, along with the layer cooling fans and heatsink fan).

title: John 3:16 RBS rev d Rolling Ball Sculpture Marble Run

description.text:
I revised the John 3:16 RBS rev c to include extra bracing so that it did not need support when 3d printed. I also removed one brace that was a problem with that rev.

The marbles and the track will probably need to be lightly sanded so that the marbles do not bounce off the track. I found it useful to roll the marble between the fingers to find bumps that need to be sanded. Running your finger over the track will help find bumps that need to be sanded. The marbles still bounce down the track and like to fly off sometimes.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G3nHviwY5G4

The older model can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:64764

It took me about 5 hours to print. Raft was used but no supports were used when I printed it.

NEW AND IMPROVED!:

I've made a shallower version and it seems to work better. The marbles on the shallower version are slightly smaller so that they ride lower within the track. This all works to keep the marbles on the track better.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YVmglPX6n9c
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-qTmpfNkaGA

I hope you enjoy it!

https://www.shapeways.com/product/A569FNM2Q/rbs-john-3-16-rev-ds-rolling-ball-sculpture-marble?optionId=61912451

Geetech MeCreator2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

15%

Lightly sand

Sand the marbles and track to get rid of bumps that will cause the marble to bounce off the track.

scripting

The original track was built with a script I made. I then took the model into tinkercad and added additional bracing to avoid needing to print with supports.

title: Cold end Friction / Traction extruder (belt driven extrusion)

description.text:
On request here is the friction extruder, as shown in my YouTube video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t-lAmIoJvJU

It works very reliable, swapping filament requires some struggle and can be improved.
More info and used components such as pulleys wil follow.

comments.text: I bought some bulk cheap ABS filament that works very well except that it has very occasional short thin spots where the diameter is only 1.5mm instead of 1.75mm. They are far enough apart (and the rest of the filament is the correct diameter) that most prints turn out OK. However whenever my conventional hobbed extruder hits a thin bit during a fast extrude, it slips and wears a groove in the filament, so extrusion stops, which obviously ruins the print. I don't want to throw away all my filament as it is otherwise good, so I am going to try a friction drive extruder such as this or http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1247952
comments.author: Cynic

comments.text:
And what kind of advantage to justify this complexity, weight, size, tricky way to load/unload the filament ,????
Any values regarding its performance ?
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: won't strip the filament if you get a hotend jam, grips all filament types without adjustments (flex, etc) ?
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
In case of a jam, the filament will have to be removed anyway. It is important to be able to dismount the whole extruder/hotend and load the filament easily. A correct hobbed gear will grip any filament and adjustment is not an issue if properly set or a different design is used .
I fail to understand why people keep using these enormous skateboard bearings and come up with such intricate lever !

description.text: Micro Planetary Gear Reducer Motor 5v, to create small robots.

Create a small robot This small motor is suitable to create small and light robots using 3d printing or not. They can work with tension between 3 and 6 volts, and has a slow pace, and small consume. With a small double transistor circuit (or a small H bridge) you can connect two of those in an Arduino board easily.

For my shop desk I ordered a power strip just to find out it didn't had any mounting holes for the intended mounting underneath my desk.
Another opportunity to get my feet wet with Fusion 360 and print something useful.

Printer:

XYZ DaVinci mini

Rafts:

No

No

Fusion 360 - Meshmixer - XYZ ware

A novice to Fusion 360 this little project allowed me to gain some basic experience. Overall not a complicated object at all. Exporting into Meshmixer and from there into XYZ ware without any interference. I had to rotate the model in XYZ ware in order to get the "backside" of the brackets down to the print bed in order to avoid any need for supports. Each bracket took about an hour to print. It has a nice firm fit around my powerstrip and came out as expected.

This is how i can alter my nozzle setting in a flash on the orca 040

I had 5 pc 30 mbar gas nozzles from my simens ranger stove to spare since it comes with 2 set, witch most do. they are almost free to get in this case totally free...
I altered the tread on them to 6 mm witch was no problem. Put them on a rod in my drilling machine and sharpened them to a tip on a Sander.
With the mendelpart v9 hot end i then moved the heat block down a bit so it connect the nozzle to the rod.
it works fine and now i can chose from 0.25 to 0.8 nossels and changen them in a flash and make this iPhone chair in just over 45 minutes ;-)

description.text: To run my new CNC machine I bought a compact mini PC. This PC came with amounting plate that could be used to mount it at the back of a monitor using the VEGA monitor mounting holes. As my monitor is mounted onto a dual monitor stand utilizing its Vega mounting holes, I created a bracket that utilizes the PC mounting plate but attaches it to the round pole of the monitor arm.

Printer:

XYZ DaVinci mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No
2 x PC holder 1 (main bracket) Mounted to the Mini PC mounting plate using the VESA mounting hole pattern Complete and in action

Fusion 360 - Meshmixer - XYZ ware

A simple training project for me with a practical use.
After measuring the size of the pole and carefully considering all details of the mounting plate I just eyeballed the overall size and made it round numbers (I work in metric). This bracket came out with a perfect fit on the first attempt.

Essentially we have 2 brackets #1 which get mounted to the mounting plate and 2 brackets #2 which holds bracket #1 to the round pole by friction. I used M4 bolts, washer and nuts to assemble.

author: Tony_D

title: FratAttack - Printable Drinking / Board Game
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Oh no! Mind-controlling aliens have invaded and only drunk people are immune? Now, only the (perpetually drunk) fraternities can save us. Join in, be the first to defeat the aliens and get yourself and your friends drunk in the process.

FratAttack is a boardgame designed for 4 or more players with a drinking component. During the game, players collect weapons to defeat the aliens, have to face over a hundreds different challenges, screw other people over and, of course, drink. Think of the game like a boardgame variation of Mario Party with alcohol involved.

The core game is designed to be completely printable and playable within 15 minutes. If you'd like something more permanent, I recommend laminating the gameboard or laser-engraving it onto a wooden board. This is still a work in progress, and I plan to add 3D-printed components such as figures to the game in the future.

If you'd like to follow development of even participate, check out the projects page on github.

This is a Cylon Raider from the Battle Star Galactica series. It's a fairly simple design but detailed enough to still be a bit of fun!

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

40

Notes:

Ideally this model should have been split into two halves to avoid support structures, however it does benefit from not needing any assembly.

Printer: FlashForge Creator Pro
Bed: Glass
Bed temp: 110
Extruder temp: 220
Filament: Standard ABS

I used ABS on this print as i wanted a nice gloss finish. I used the cold acetone vapor method for an hour and a half. This involved lining a sealed PTFE box with acetone soaked kitchen towel and placing the model on a foil base (to ensure that it did not stick).

I attempted to time-lapse the process but the light got turned off so i have no useful footage :(. I can only upload a pic of the box i used.

I put together a short video of the some of the various stages that a 3D printed model goes through. Ideally this model should have been split into two halves to avoid support structures, however it does benefit from not needing any assembly.

The model is not very detailed but it has just enough to show of the iconic shape of the Cylon Raider.

description.text:
This is a Sextant, an instrument that sailors use to calculate their latitude with, by measuring the angle between the Sun (or some other star) and the horizon.

There is no fixed scale yet so you´ll have to print one yourself using this guide here: http://www.tecepe.com.br/nav/XTantProject.htm

Use M3 and M2 screws and nuts to hold it all together (using glue is also possible but make sure the parts that need to move can move!)

Oh and you will need two 35 x 15 mm Mirrors, ideally without glass, just polished metal so there is no refraction.
Idea You can learn some basic astronomy and get an idea about how sailors used to work on the big sailing ships. And it is fun to play with.

Useful pages to check http://www.tecepe.com.br/nav/XTantProject.htm
http://www.robinsdocksideshop.com/how_to_use_a_sextant.htm
http://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Sextant
http://www.clipperlight.com/howusesextant.html

comments.text: I plan to adapt this to the side of my telescope mount to help aim into the stars, a digital readout is used but is hard to read in the dark and the old sextent made from 2 blank CDs and a pendulum looks too crude for the $$astronomy gang$$, :o)).  Thanks.

title: Pergo French Door Spring Ball Door Latch Replacement ver 2

description.text:
It's odd to remix your own design. :) See the original for a better description of this item. Wow my first design and printing it looked like !crap! compared to what I can do today!

Version 2 and reworked it in solid works. Wow what a better model than 123Design!
I printed 6 of them in ABS at .2 100%

I find that if you print it upside down at 195 degrees with supports, it prints the best and uses the lest amount of filament. I included a picture of my simplify3D position.

As mentioned in the original, I've never had one of these swivel around on me so the key way idea is not needed. They stay in place. Also with Simply3D I didn't need anything but the tweezers to push (yes push,not grind) the support material away. This print might be the #1 case of proof why Simplfy3D is worth it's cost.

description.text:
No matter what your cause, signs can be awkward to hold. So whether it's a protest, or your kid's ball game, these should upgrade your sign nicely. Designed to hold foam board, and with a little chalkboard or whiteboard paint, it would be east to change your sign as needed.

Friendly reminder that the March for Science is April 22

Should fit almost every printer out there, designed to fit on even the smallest .

BOM

1x 5/8 inch dowel rod, available at most craft or hardware stores.
Foam board or cardboard
1x #4 wood screw
1x cable tie

Quick Print version also requires double sided tape or hot glue.

Optional Chalkboard or whiteboard paint

Instructions

make your sign on foamboard or cardboard or paint your foamboard with chalkboard/whiteboard paint. Let dry.

use a #4 wood screw to attach the top sign holder to one end of the dowel.

slide the board into the slot

add the bottom holder and secure with a cable tie or glue.

add handle (optional) to other end of dowel.

title: Door latch warning for temporary excursion

description.text:
About three times a week, I like to leave my home and go for a quick jog around the area. It clears the mind, strengthens the body and my scant little loin cloth is a big hit with the ladies. The thing is... that's pretty much all I'm wearing. There are no pockets for keys or garage door openers so I usually end up leaving the front door unlocked behind me during this brief excursion.

If there's ever a chance that a housemate awakes during this time and decides to stumble to the front door (in their usual hungover state) they just might summon the temporary lucidity to twist the latch back to the locked state (and then head to fridge for another beer and pass out a few moments later as I'm trying to climb in through the window or something). Pfft. Housemates.

SO... I made this doo-hickey. Just put it on the latch in the unlocked state on your way out and your fellow heroin-infused home dwellers won't even touch it. It's shaped a bit like a stop sign so they don't even need to be able to read to comprehend it's very simple message of "don't lock out the loin-cloth guy!". Yeah. You get it. Pfft. Heroin-users...

Fits latches that are within 15.9mm x 46mm

If you found this useful, please share and be sure to peruse my other submissions which are almost as varied as they are many:

http://www.thingiverse.com/3E8/designs

Enjoy!

February 11th, 2016 update: I added another, larger version, with jagged little edges because... (gosh darnit!) one of my housemates managed to still lock me out because his partially-numbed early-morning fingers couldn't feel the difference between the usual door latch and this thing. Lame... but a legitimate concern. I've addressed it with the larger 'stop sign'-looking version. Happy excursioning!
